column1: The second meiotic division during oogenesis begins:
column6: None of the answers is true
column8: Meiosis II begins at ovulation when the secondary oocyte is formed and arrests in metaphase II until fertilization.

column1: From which germ layer develop the smooth muscle cells of internal organs:
column8: Visceral smooth muscle derives from splanchnopleuric (visceral) mesoderm associated with endodermal organs.

column1: The merging of which structures contributes to the development of the face?
column2: Maxillary and mandibular processes, frontonasal prominence
column8: Normal facial development requires fusion of frontonasal prominence with maxillary and mandibular processes.

column1: How long does normally capacitation of the semen take?
column8: Sperm capacitation occurs in the female reproductive tract and normally requires about 5–7 hours.

column1: Which of the following structures originates from the endoderm:
column8: Endoderm forms epithelial linings of urogenital sinus derivatives including prostate and vaginal epithelium.

column1: How does the female reproductive tract assist sperm migration?
column3: by uterine contractions during orgasm and strands of cervical mucus
column4: by a chemical secreted by the egg
column8: Sperm migration is aided by uterine contractions, cervical mucus alignment, and chemotactic signals from the oocyte.

column1: At which developmental stage appears the allantois?
column6: None of the answers is true
column8: The allantois appears in early week 3 as an endodermal diverticulum from the yolk sac.

column1: Which cytoskeleton is associated with the adherent (adherens) junction?
column8: Adherens junctions link actin filaments of adjacent cells via cadherins and catenins.

column1: Which type of cell junction is the adherent junction:
column8: Adherens junctions are cell–cell junctions connected to the actin cytoskeleton.
Meissner corpuscles are rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors for light touch and low-frequency vibration.

column1: Which of the listed proteins does not interact with actin filament:
column8: Kinesin is a microtubule motor protein, not an actin-associated protein.

column1: The transport from/to the nucleus takes place via:
column8: Nuclear pore complexes mediate all regulated nucleocytoplasmic transport.

column1: The brush border of the enterocytes is the light microscopical equivalent of:
column8: The brush border corresponds to densely packed microvilli on the apical surface of enterocytes.

column1: The basic units of chromatin are called:
column8: Nucleosomes consist of DNA wrapped around a histone octamer and form the basic unit of chromatin.

column1: Which of the following answers is TRUE? (Ruffini corpuscles)
column8: Ruffini corpuscles respond to sustained pressure, skin stretch, and low-frequency vibration.

column1: Which type of cartilage tissue forms the template for the endochondral bone formation?
column8: Endochondral ossification proceeds by replacement of a hyaline cartilage model.

column2: transformation from one subtype to another subtype of the same type of basic tissue
column8: Metaplasia is a reversible adaptive change replacing one differentiated cell type with another of the same tissue lineage.

column1: The average life-time of erythrocytes in the circulatory system is:
column8: Normal erythrocyte lifespan is approximately 120 days before splenic removal.

column1: According to the shape of the secretory portion of the exocrine glands, they are classified as:
column8: Classification by shape includes tubular and acinar (alveolar) glands.
